intro: Silene acutidentata, commonly known as the sharp-toothed catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and woodland edges. Its leaves are lance-shaped with serrated edges, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits containing numerous seeds. Silene acutidentata is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in partial shade to full sun.
